doc.title: J.P.Morgan
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/Taishin Financial Holdings 1H25 results in line better banking performance offset by weaker non-bank earningsTaishin Fin_2025-08-31

passages.text: Taishin's 1H25 results were largely in line with our expectations as double- digit earnings growth at the banking operations was offset by weaker securities and life insurance operations. We revise up our earnings forecasts by \(55 / 149\%\) for FY25/26E to factor in the consolidation of Shinkong and reiterate our UW rating with a new PT of NT\\$14.4 to reflect the merger impact and moving forward our valuation base to Dec- 26.

Group 1H25 profits of NT\\$10.2bn were down \(3\%\) YoY and implied an annualized ROE of \(10.6\%\) . Taishin Bank delivered \(14\%\) earnings growth on the back of \(7\%\) PPOP growth, but this was more than offset by over a \(60\%\) profit decline at Taishin Sec, while Taishin Life would have suffered losses if excluding the NT\\$2.6bn one- time contribution from the release of excess liability reserves under the regulatory supportive measures in June.

What was positive: sequential margin expansion and improving operating efficiency at Taishin Bank. Reported and adjusted (including swaps revenues) NIM were up 3/2bps QoQ in 2Q25 supported by lower funding costs, improving deposit mix, as well as higher LDR in the FCY portfolio; management is still confident of delivering further NIM improvement in 2H25 and reaffirms the full- year target of 6- 8bps expansion YoY in FY25. Costincome ratio inched down to \(53\%\) in 1H25 from \(55\%\) in 1H24 on the back of double- digit revenue growth momentum; management guided that all M&A related employee settlement expenses have been fully recognized by Shinkong in March and thus no further impact, but consolidation would incur extra costs so potential cost synergies would materialize after two years at the earliest.

What was negative: higher credit costs at Taishin Bank and elevated hedging costs at Taishin Life. Credit costs inched up to 14bps in 1H25 from 11bps in 1H24, but still at benign levels, while management guided only NT \(\) 2bn\$ risky exposure related to US tariffs after reviewing its corporate customers so limited impact on credit costs if any. Investment returns at Taishin Life dwindled by 127bps YoY to \(3.2\%\) in 1H25 dragged by elevated hedging costs, but Taishin Life has applied for the release of excess liability reserves, of which \(50\% /50\%\) into FX reserves/revenues.

Reiterate: W. 1H25 results suggest the banking operation has performed largely in line with peers but the securities and life insurance operations were inferior to peers. However, management has not provided much key information related to the Shinkong merger, such as goodwill, PPA amortization, and post- merger dividend policies, and thus we see limited upside catalysts for both consensus earnings and the share price in the near future despite the underperformance YTD.

We maintain our UW rating as management has not provided much key information related to the Shinkong merger and postmerger dividend policies; thus we see limited upside catalysts for both consensus earnings and share price in the near future despite the underperformance YTD.
Our P/BV- based Dec- 26 PT of NT\$14.4 is based on a 0.85x P/B (FY26E) and implies a 8.1x P/E (FY26E).

The total deal size is finalized at NT\$251bn, and Taishin issued common shares of 11.98bn at NT\$17.4 per share and H- class preferred shares of 3.1bn at NT\$10 per share. Based on our calculation, pro forma BVPS for common shares would be NT \$15.0 vs. reported NT\$12.8 at Taishin as of 2Q25. Management commented that both goodwill and PPA are still under discussion, but if we use the NT\$656bn amount guided by management back in April, implied goodwill could be around NT \$400bn if no excess liability reserves, of which the amount, if any, would be further squeezed after NT\$63bn was released to FX reserves in June. We note NT\$400bn goodwill would be equivalent to almost the entire common equity base for the new entity, TS Holdings, thus the criteria of goodwill impairment test would be very critical since any potential impairment could have a material impact on book value and profits during any single year.

On the other hand, PPA amortization would result in additional earnings accretion for the new entity going forward; the amount would vary in individual years subject to management guidance once finalized but our ballpark estimate is NT\$10- 20bn p.a. in the coming years. Although PPA amortization is an accounting gain, current regulations do not restrict such part of the earnings from dividend distribution, unless there is any specific window guidance from FSC.

Due to limited information at the current stage and no clear guidance on dividend policies, it is difficult for investors to assess the potential impact on PPA amortization and goodwill impairments; thus we see limited catalysts to drive share price outperformance in the near future and expect valuation discounts at TS Holdings over other insurance- centric peers such as Cathay.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the

Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
